metadata.name: RGB Elementary Cellular Automaton #783
metadata.description:
Stephen Wolfram's Elementary Cellular Automaton where 3 different rules are drawn in the Red, Green and Blue color components of the image.

Rules are selected randomly among a pre-selection of 53 rules from which nice behaviors emerge.

Tokens can have a cell size in the [1; 20] range.

metadata.name: Root #12
metadata.description:
Root, by Matthew Plummer-Fernandez (2022). A pseudo-simulation of plant intelligence and root systems. Each root apex splinters into more apexes that follow similar trajectories in swarm-like patterns. To illustrate a basic response to their surroundings, each root system is confined to an invisible container that the root tips appear to either inspect or repel from, framing the final state. The system is sensitive to the space containing it, so it may grow in another way on different screen sizes. 

Inspired by The Revolutionary Genius of Plants: A New Understanding of Plant Intelligence and Behavior, by scientist and author Stefano Mancuso.

Press 's' key in live mode to save a png.

The code that generates this work also contains an essay titled 'Root: hashing out the concept of regenerative art'

Press the '/' key (a symbol used for the 'root' directory) in live mode to save the essay as a txt file (best viewed copy/pasted into a word processor).

metadata.name: Tormented Textures I #512
metadata.description:
Create your own monoprint. Sourced from My own print work made on an 111-year-old, cast iron printing press.

There are 4,914 possible combinations for this piece. With an edition size of 666, 4,200+ will never exist. Which one(s) will you get?

For every 6 that you collect, you will receive 3 airdropped NFTs from My next generative project.

metadata.name: Jubilee #77
metadata.description:
Jubilee is a flow field festival celebrating creation. Ribbons scattered through a space meet one another, overlap, and are generally at the mercy of the forces acting upon them. But collectively, what complex forms can they create?

Canvas size is 1200 x 1600 pixels, in either portrait or landscape.

To change canvas size:

[1] 1200 x 1600 
[2] 2400 x 3200 
[3] 4800 x 6400

[s] will save a png at the chosen resolution.

metadata.name: Ordered Chaos #15
metadata.description:
Ordered Chaos is a dynamic interplay of precision and distortion, where structure and movement converge to form a captivating visual symphony. The artwork unfolds as a mosaic of geometric grids, vibrant hues, and flowing deformations, creating a sense of controlled entropy.

Bold colors—emerald greens, electric blues, fiery reds, and glowing yellows—dominate the composition, their contrasts breathing life into each segment. Rigid, orderly grids anchor the piece, yet these are disrupted by undulating lines and warped forms, suggesting an unseen force bending structure into fluidity.

The composition balances tension and harmony. Some sections radiate stability, showcasing clean, linear patterns, while others twist and contort, evoking motion and transformation. These distortions ripple across the surface, connecting the fragmented forms into a single cohesive flow—where chaos is not destruction but evolution.

Ordered Chaos reflects the duality of modern existence: a world shaped by digital precision and organic spontaneity. It invites viewers to immerse themselves in its patterns, to see order and disorder as two sides of the same whole, and to embrace the beauty that emerges when the two coexist in perfect tension.

metadata.name: ION TRAP #257
metadata.description:
Inside the ION TRAP, reality is suspended. Particles hang motionless, captured in a glowing web of energy that hums with an endless, static resonance. Time has ceased to flow, frozen in a tension where neither motion nor decay is possible. The trap's design reflects the peak of retro-futuristic ambition; crafted to transcend the very limits of nature. It stands as a testament to the brilliance — and the final misstep — of a civilization that sought to master the fabric of existence, only to unwittingly freeze their world forever.

***

Press ⬅️➡️ to rotate scene.

Press [1/2/4/6/8/0] to change resolution to 1/2/4/6/8/10K along the short edge. 

Press [s] to save a png at the current resolution. Saving at higher resolutions may not work on all browsers (tested: all resolutions work using Safari on an M2 mac. Up to 4K work on Chrome). 

Press [p] to restart the draw animation and initiate download of png frames at current resolution until drawing is complete. Typically generates 500-600 images. Can be assembled into a video / GIF with your software of choice. Recommend doing this at 2K resolution.

100% code generative artwork written in javascript using the p5.js library.

Bleaker 2024

metadata.name: Undercurrent #48
metadata.description:
Undercurrent invites you to have fun combining animated layers of patterns and cartoonish noise.

Controls
--------
[Space] or click/tap to toggle animation
[A] to reset and pause animation
[S] to save file at current resolution
[L] to save file at 4000x4000

metadata.name: round #22
metadata.description:
I am trying to create pieces with simple shapes like circle, rectangle and triangle.
And the "round" shape gives them warmth.

metadata.name: Diamond Fractal Fire #153
metadata.description:
Diamond Fractal Fire interposes recursively generated poetry with similarly recursive fractal imagery. Each text (unique for each mint, but always 20 sentences in length) is generated by a custom context-free grammar algorithm, fed with lists of words selected by the creator. The fractal pattern in each edition is a variation on a Koch snowflake fractal, one of the earliest fractals described by mathematicians. These fractals grow over time at varying rates, and pulse with varying color ranges using Perlin noise, eventually filling the screen.


Push `h` to save high resolution PNG and JPG images of the complete fractal pattern (takes a moment to process)
Push `s` to save PNG and JPG images of the current browser view (with current browser window dimensions and resolution)
Push `v` to begin recording canvas as a video (with current browser window dimensions), then push `v` again to save the video
Push `f` to toggle fullscreen mode
Push `p` to toggle zoom pause
Push `r` to toggle zoom reverse
Push `c` to toggle color shift pause
Push `l` to toggle low resolution mode (improves framerate)


The animation is somewhat computationally expensive, and so it runs best on contemporary laptop and desktop computers. Mobile devices and older computers may experience low frame rates. Captured video quality may vary depending on compute and browser limitations. The animation is responsive (it will adapt to any screen or window size), and resizing your browser window also will restart the animation.

Color floors and variances represent ranges for Hue using a Hue/Saturation/Brightness (HSB) color model. Velocities represent (subtle) zoom speed differences. Noise increment and start values affect the rate and variation of color shifts.

In addition to the author's code, Diamond Fractal Fire relies on the p5.js library.

metadata.name: Genuary 32nd - Plantae #21
metadata.description:
part of the Genuary 32 party

hope I made piter proud

metadata.name: Truchet Decay #26
metadata.description:
There is no chaos, only order differently distributed.

Truchet tiles are warped and twisted to fit into a conformally mapped grid. 


To change canvas size:

[1] 1200 x 1200 (default)
[2] 2400 x 2400
[3] 4800 x 4800

[s] will save a png at the chosen resolution.


Just javascript.
Noise provided by OpenSimplexNoise.js

metadata.name: Void Divergence #168
metadata.description: A void disruption that creates a random universe.

metadata.name: Colour study #1
metadata.description:
This algorithm was written entirely in p5.js and is made up of a vector-based particle system with colour inheritance.

The colours have all been hand-picked from photographs I took on my travels (mostly the Greek islands, Spanish countryside, and California) and this work explores whether, and to what extent, the colour palette can abstract, decontextualise and transmit the feelings captured in the photographs to you, someone I (probably) have not even met.

Feel free to message me on discord or twitter (@cryptotallzy) if you would like a copy of the photograph from which a colour palette was drawn from.

Press 'S' to save.

tallzy | 2022

metadata.name: Hillhouse #84
metadata.description:
On every important holiday of my childhood, I would return to my hometown, a village in a hilly area. The mist in the morning would have a psychedelic texture, like water ripples under the smudge of the deep blue sky. But at sunrise, the atmosphere becomes lively. All year round, spring, summer, autumn and winter, colourful and dreamlike.

The buildings in my hometown are white walls and black tiles. The fog in the village is very close to the ground, and the terrain is relatively undulating. I can often see rows of angular eaves and white walls penetrating the fog on other hillsides, like houses standing in the clouds. At that time, I always liked to climb up the hillside under the sunset after dinner, looking down at the village surrounded by clouds and mist after the rain. I could always stay at the top of the mountain and watch the clouds change from orange-red to blue. I didn't leave until the sky turned completely black. After I left the village, whenever I described such a scene with my friends, I would call such a building: Hillhouse.

I'm not in China now, and I don't know when I'll be able to see the misty landscape of my hometown again to create Hillhouse, a memorial to the village that inspired my aesthetics during my childhood.

I noticed many of my friends said after seeing my works that my townhouse is like a mountain. My original idea was to appropriately enlarge the proportion of the roof in the picture because I tried to balance the natural landscape and humanistic value in the work. Moreover, I also deliberately strengthened the corners and some obvious small pavilion buildings to make it different from the mountains. But, of course, art depends on personal understanding, so that's fine.


Mint at 188 tez, I will provide a 1/1 customised video NFT, physical printed work, and one WL spot for my following 2 projects on fxhash. You can choose your favourite palette and mountain style in our UI system and the soundtrack first. Then I will create a 20-sec video version NFT for you. The sound is originally created by @Dreminor. 

In terms of printed work, it will be printed on museum quality acid-free paper by giclee print technique. It will never fade 100 yrs. And the printed work will have my signature and seal on it. So yes I will give it to you with no charge, except the delivery fee requested from the delivery company.

I also considered secondary market transactions for collectors who minted at 188. I will offer a NEW customized video NFT and a NEW printed work to collectors who purchase the token minted in 188tez for more than 188tez on the secondary market. The video NFT is free but I will charge 100tez for the new printed work.

Mint at 138 tez, I will provide a printed work and one WL spot for my next project on fxhash.

Mint at 64 tez. I will provide one WL spot for my next project on fxhash.


Btw, the computational expense in this project is high, so if you cannot open live, please try to use a better computer to generate or use Visual Studio Code. If you cannot solve this problem, feel free to contact me, I would like to offer help.

Due to some reasons, the preview will be different from the generative artwork. So pls open live to have a look and it will be much better than preview.

This project is created by Arctic--Cc and Van.

metadata.name: Interpolator #34
metadata.description:
Recently, while scrolling through my Twitter feed, I came across something about the bicubic interpolation method, which reminded me of a funny joke my professor once shared during a lecture on numerical methods:

"Bicubic interpolation is like ordering pizza from four different kitchens at once and then making them agree on the recipe. Each slice ends up exactly how you want it, but it takes way more effort than just eating plain bread 😄".

This algorithm truly tries to account for all surrounding points to achieve the smoothest, most natural result — a real perfectionist in the world of interpolation! This mention inspired me to revisit bicubic interpolation, but this time from an artist's perspective.

Bicubic interpolation is a method for interpolating data points on a two-dimensional grid. It creates smoother surfaces compared to bilinear or nearest-neighbor interpolation. While bilinear interpolation considers only 4 pixels (2×2), bicubic interpolation takes into account 16 pixels (4×4), which is why it’s computationally more demanding. Here I fill the canvas pixel by pixel, using only the bicubic interpolation method to achieve smooth color gradients. A bit of chaos is introduced to the overall composition through my custom metric for pixel placement.

Press S or double-click to save as PNG.

Kyiv, 11.2024.
